history.content: CS70 will not be webcast.  That means maximum enrollment will be 744.  The combined enrollment and waitlist is currently 885.  Some students currently enrolled will drop to make room for some students currently on the waitlist but we can't promise how many that will be.

children.subject: Do keep in mind that the university moved the drop deadline much earlier this semester, so we're not going to be able to have the first midterm before that deadline any more.  We honestly don't know what effect that will have on enrollment (it might result in fewer people dropping because they can't use the first midterm as a litmus test, but we can't be sure until we see the final numbers), so it's definitely good to have a backup plan in case that trend doesn't repeat.
A lot of people tend to drop 70 so I wouldn't be too worried.
At least some people will definitely drop. Also, reserved seats don't matter once adjustment starts.

I just got an enrollment update saying I cannot be enrolled in the cs70 because I do not qualify for any of the reserved seats. This could possibly change during the adjustment period and throughout the first weeks of the semester as people will drop the class, correct?

history.content: We (the head TAs) had a long discussion with the professors today about the possibility of expanding 70 to let people on the waitlist in and...well, we weren't able to make much headway convincing them that it was worth the extra workload on the staff that would incur.  It's not guaranteed that we won't expand the class, but we definitely recommend having a backup plan in case you can't get in.

children.subject: It has been webcast in the past, but the professors want to encourage more students to come to live lectures, and they think that not having webcasts is the best way to do that.
This may be true but now less students can enroll. I personally thought to phase II cs70 because I thought they would expand to fit as many students as possible but now I am on the waitlist

What's the reason for wanting students to come to live lectures? I learn so much better with webcasts considering that I can go at my own pace and that there are less distractions. I am sure there are many other students who share the same sentiment. 

I think letting students decide their favorite method of lecture would the best, no?

I agree that web casted lectures have been much more beneficial for me rather than attending live lecture. There are so many distractions around me sometimes, or sometimes I am unable to see the board clearly, or take notes fast enough. I really think web casted lectures have been really helpful for my learning. I think this policy may also have a disadvantage in that the auditorium/lecture hall will always be completely full. From my experience, I have not been able to concentrate enough in lecture halls that have been filled with students as there are multiple distractions coming from all around me. I am sure several students feel the same way about the benefits of a webcasted lecture.
Why isn't cs70 being webcasted? I thought that it was webcasted in the past.
Just to reiterate: this is not a policy. Instructors have always been able to web-cast or not as they see fit.  That has not changed.

history.content:
What are the chances I will get off the waitlist for cs70 if I just enrolled (phase 2 #193 on waitlist) and I am intended L&S CS?

Does cs70 have any plans of expanding to accommodate more intended L&S CS students?
